III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Intervention standards and prohibitions
Title
1

Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention: (a) Any type of physical punishment including, but
not limited to: (ii) Hitting or striking, throwing, kicking, pulling, or
pushing a youth on any part of their body.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 4/22/24, two youth left the facility due to reported ongoing
abuse. Youth were picked up by LE. Staff were pushing youth
around and grabbing the youth's arms and twisting them behind
their backs and lifting them to control them. Youth has scratches
on their foot and hand from recent staff abuse.
Investigation Interviews:
On 04/23/2024 a joint email was sent to FCW by DHHS Specialist
advising of investigation involving youth.
On 04/24/2024 a telephone call was made to Complainant. A
voice message was left to advise of any additional concerns.
All of the following interviews were conducted at the facility
on 04/24/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker unless
otherwise noted.
Program Director was interviewed and advised of the allegations
of the complaint. Copies of the incident reports and agency policy
were requested. The DHHS Specialist implemented a safety plan
with the agency that involved them continuing to follow AWOL
protocol, complete incident reports for each resident that goes
AWOL, and contact DCWL and foster care as required per policy
when residents leave the building.
Youth A was interviewed and admitted that he ran away and was
AWOL. He talked about going to the hospital with a friend from
the police station, but refused to answer any additional questions
about what occurred when he was AWOL and whether or not staff
engage in any inappropriate verbal or physical intervention with
him.
Youth B was interviewed and admitted he ran away and was
AWOL. He reported running because kids were annoying him.
He reported getting money from random strangers at the gas
station and then getting on the bus with Youth A. He provided
several variations of his story, but essentially reported that he rode
2

the bus to a park and unknowingly ended up in Birmingham, MI.
Youth B reported someone called the police and he and Youth A
were taken to the hospital. He reported that Wolverine staff never
hit him, punched him, touched him or restrained him while he was
attempting to go AWOL or while he was at the facility. Youth B
confirmed that staff attempt to stop youth from going AWOL and
will tell them not to leave. He added that if kids don’t run, they get
rewarded with trips to the movies and airtime.
Youth C was interviewed and admitted that he also went AWOL
from the facility a couple nights ago. He confirmed that staff make
attempts to get kids to come back by verbally redirecting them and
he denied that they physically restrain. He stated that staff will
follow kids until they can no longer see them.
Youth D was interviewed and recalled that he does not recall
youth going AWOL two nights ago. He reported that staff try to
convince kids not to go AWOL by blocking the door or standing in
front of them. Youth D stated he has never seen staff become
physically aggressive toward kids. He ended his interview by
saying "no one abused them."
Staff 1 was interviewed and advised that he has worked at
Wolverine Since 04/01/24 as a Youth Specialist. Staff 1 reported
that on 04/22/24 both Youth A and Youth B asked to go for a walk
after dinner and crossed the street without permission and refused
to come back when asked. Staff 1 stated he followed the youth
down the street and through a yard until he lost line of sight. He
reported to supervision via radio that the youth had went AWOL.
He reported that he completed an incident report and denied that
he made any attempt to restrain the youth. He denied any type of
physical intervention was used and further denied that he has ever
used inappropriate physical intervention with the youth at the
facility.
All of the following interviews were conducted at the facility
on 05/9/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker unless
otherwise noted.
Supervisor 1 was interviewed and reported he worked as a shift
supervisor on the afternoon shift from 2:00PM to 10:00PM. He
confirmed that he was familiar with Youth A and Youth B. They
had finished dinner one night and asked to go for a walk, went
AWOL, and ended up in Birmingham. He stated he did not see
the boys run off but noted that Staff 1 was keeping them updated
through the walkie as he followed them until he lost line of sight.
3

Supervisor 1 reported that they talk to residents about not going
AWOL and attempt to deter them. He denied knowledge that any
staff had used physical intervention in an attempt to prevent the
youth from going AWOL or used physical intervention any time
during this incident.
Youth E was interviewed and reported that when youth AWOL
they are not allowed to go on outings. He reported that staff try to
redirect youth from going AWOL by talking to them about the
dangers. He reported that staff are not allowed to put hands on
residents and that they verbally redirect youth to come back or
stay inside. Youth E was not aware of Youth A or Youth B being
physically harmed by a staff member or other residents when they
went AWOL.
Youth F was interviewed and reported that staff encourage
residents not to leave and go AWOL. He reported that staff do not
touch residents. He reported that when residents return from
AWOL they are searched and then go for a medical clearance
before they are allowed back in the building. Youth F denied
seeing any staff use physical intervention with youth that attempt
to leave the facility.
Youth G was interviewed and confirmed that he has seen youth
go AWOL. He reported that staff will usually follow for a certain
distance and then let them go. He denied any knowledge of staff
using psychical intervention toward youth when attempting to
AWOL.
On 05/22/2024 a DHHS Case Conference was held. DHHS
Specialist advised that there were no finding of abuse or neglect.
Preliminary report of no areas of non-compliance reported from
DCWL consultant.
Documents reviewed:
Detroit Police Department Police Report #240422-0363:
Officer reported being dispatched regarding two juveniles. Officer
arrived and spoke with bus driver who stated that two unattended
youth go on the bus. Officer approached youth in the back of the
bus and found them to be underdressed for the weather. Youth
were noted to have bruises and scrapes on their legs that
appeared to be caused by a fall. The youth reported not wanting
to return to Wolverine. Since there were concerns, both youth
were transported to the hospital for evaluation.
4

Wolverine Agency AWOL Policy: Staff will make efforts to
verbally redirect the truanting client and will offer the client support
and alternatives to truancy. If a non supervising staff is available,
they will walk with the client and continue to provide verbal
support and redirection encouraging the client not to truant.
Staff supervising the group will immediately call a group attention
to support and maintain the security of the group. Staff will
maintain control of the group and conduct an immediate head
count. Staff will immediately notify the Youth Care Specialist
Supervisor on duty when line of sight is lost, no later than 15
minutes from loss of line of sight (when youth is determined
AWOL). The Youth Specialist Supervisor will contact the Lead
Supervisor and Program Management who will provide oversight
for incident management. The youth specialist supervisor will
ensure law enforcement is notified immediately (no more than 5
minutes from when youth is determined AWOL.) Staff will report
the following information immediately to the Youth Care Specialist
Supervisor on duty Name(s) of the truant client(s), Approximate
time and location of the truancy, The direction of travel the
client(s) was/were headed, Whether the client(s) appear(s) to
present a danger to self or others in the community,
circumstances prior to the truancy, risk assessment and other
pertinent safety related information. Staff will notify law
enforcement and program director. Client specifics will be
provided to Law enforcement and an IR will be completed.
Incident Report for AWOL of Youth A – IR was written by Staff
1 and indicated that Youth A and Youth B asked to go for a walk
after dinner and then took off running. Staff followed and verbally
redirected them to return, but youth refused. Law enforcement
contacted and report number noted.
Incident Report for AWOL of Youth B - IR was written by Staff 1
and indicated that Youth A and Youth B asked to go for a walk
after dinner and then took off running. Staff followed and verbally
redirected them to return, but youth refused. Law enforcement
contacted and report number noted.
Analysis The agency is found to be in compliance with the licensing rule.
Both youth and staff were interviewed and there was not sufficient
evidence to confirm that staff engaged in any type of inappropriate
forms of intervention with the youth.
Conclusion Not Violation Established
5

Rule Code Youth nutrition
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4149
Section (1) A licensee shall provide a minimum of 3 nutritious edible meals
Description daily unless medically contraindicated and documented.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Residents at Wolverine are not being feed.
Investigation Interviews:
All of the following interviews were conducted at the facility
on 04/24/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker unless
otherwise noted.
Program Director was interviewed and confirmed that youth at
the facility are provided with three meals per day and snacks. She
further advised that a meal schedule is posted and provided a
copy for review.
Youth A was interviewed and advised that he “doesn’t want to talk
about food”.
Youth B was interviewed and advised that he is provided food at
the facility. He reported that he gets food “everyday”. He stated
that he does not like the lunch and dinner but likes the breakfast.
He further stated that he likes it when they have pizza.
Youth C was interviewed and reported that he gets enough food
and denied he gets old food.
Youth D was interview and reported he gets enough food and
denied there has ever been a time when he did not get food. He
denied that he has ever heard other youth complain about food at
the facility.
Staff 1 was interviewed and denied that youth have ever
complained to him about not having food. He reported that he
works second shift and has seen dinner and snacks served
regularly.
All of the following interviews were conducted at the facility
on 05/9/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker unless
otherwise noted.
6

Supervisor 1 was interviewed and denied that residents have
ever complained to him about not getting food and confirmed that
they are served three meals a day and snacks at 3pm and 7pm.
Shift Coordinator 1 was interviewed and denied that youth have
ever told him or complained of not getting food. He stated that
youth sometimes complain about the options, but food is always
available. He also reported that Peanut Butter and Jelly
sandwiches are sometimes available as an alternative.
Youth E was interviewed and reported that he eats three times
per day and gets two snacks.
Youth F was interviewed and confirmed that he had lunch. He
also reported that he gets food three times per day and also two
snacks.
Documents Reviewed:
Meal schedule was reviewed and confirmed to be posted in the
facility.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as there was not enough
information to support allegation that youth at the facility are not
receiving food. All youth interviews confirmed that youth receive
at least three meals per day, in addition to snacks.
Conclusion No Violation Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules.
